# The github
https://github.com/MCOtto/CONPS.JCPOS

We propagated and reared four forb and four grass species in a crossed design that measured plant growth and survival in 1) three types of soil (peat moss, a mineral and compost mix, and native garden soil), 2) with and without fertilization, and 3) with three planting dates (July 11, August 14, September 11). We coordinated three volunteer events to install the grown plant material in a restoration site on North Table Mountain Park. We coordinated biweekly ecological monitoring events to measure the success of these plants in the field. We engaged 114 volunteer community scientists to conduct monitoring protocols. 

Hypothesis 1: Native seeds have variable germination rates that are regulated by environmental conditions. 
Null Hypothesis 1: Environmental conditions do not affect seed germination rates.  Hypothesis 2: There is a difference in plant growth due to soil type.  
Null Hypothesis 2: There is no difference in plant growth due to soil type. 
Hypothesis 4: There is a difference in plant growth with fertilization. 
Null Hypothesis 4: There is no difference in plant growth with fertilization. 
Hypothesis 5: There is a difference in plant growth due to planting date.  
Null Hypothesis 5: There is no difference in plant growth due to planting date. 

ACMI Forb Achillea millefolium common yarrow
SYER Forb Symphyotrichum ericoides white aster
ARLU Forb Artemisia ludoviciana white mountain sage/ silver wormwood
HEVI Forb Heterotheca villosa hairy goldenaster
PASM Grass Pascopyrum smithii western wheatgrass
BOGR Grass Bouteloua gracilis blue grama
NAVI Grass Nassella viridula green needle
HECO Grass Hesperostipa comata needle and thread grass
